history.content:
I don't completely follow your question/comment so sorry for any misunderstanding.

I agree that P(0,0) = 0.  

For i\geq 1, P(i,0) = \delta(x_1,GAP) + \delta(x_2,GAP) + ... + \delta(x_i,GAP), right?

Which is what the algorithm does?  

Sorry, I don't really follow what you're proposing instead?

--Eric

children.subject:
This seems correct to me:

   P(1,1)=max{δ(GAP,y1)+δ(x1,GAP),δ(GAP,y1)+δ(x1,GAP),δ(x1,y1)}.

For alignment you either match x1 and y1 -- the last case, or

you match x1 with GAP and y1 with GAP.  You can't do x1 with GAP and

y1 with nothing?  What does it align with?  If it's a mutation/substitution then

you pay \delta(x1,y1).  If it's a pair of insertions/deletions then you pay

for two GAP's.  Right?

--Eric

I had a similar question, let me see if I can phrase it differently:

If $$P(i,0) = \sum_{m=1}^{i} \delta(x_m,GAP)$$ and $$P(0,j) = \sum_{m=1}^{j} \delta(GAP,y_m)$$, then $$P(1,0) = \delta(x_1,GAP)$$ and $$P(0,1) = \delta(GAP,y_1)$$

 

So, $$P(1,1) = \max\{ P(0,1)+\delta(x_1,GAP), P(1,0)+\delta(GAP,y_1), P(0,0)+\delta(x_1,y_1)\}$$ is the same as $$P(1,1) = \max\{ \delta(GAP,y_1)+\delta(x_1,GAP), \delta(GAP,y_1)+\delta(x_1,GAP), \delta(x_1,y_1)\}$$.

The question is why P(1,1) isn't simply

$$P(1,1) = \max\{ \delta(x_1,GAP), \delta(GAP,y_1), \delta(x_1,y_1)\}$$ (which would be the case if $$\forall{i}$$ $$P(i,0)=0$$) and $$\forall{j}$$ $$P(j,0)=0$$), since this corresponds to the rewards for our 3 options: 1) match $$x_1$$ with GAP, 2) match $$y_1$$ with GAP, and 3) match $$x_1$$ with $$y_1$$.

Thoughts? Perhaps we've been looking at this too long and we're going cross-eyed :)

history.content:
For 6.26, the author goes on to warn how the base cases P(0,j) and P(i,0) are not zero. My understanding is that they need to be zero, index i=j=0 holds no data to compare. Here, we insert gaps, but we would not want to insert a gap twice for the same comparison. That is,

for j = i = 1

the term delta( GAP , y_1 ) + S ( 1 , 0 ) should just be initial score delta( GAP , y_1 ) (that is, S ( 1 , 0 ) = 0 it does not add to the score, there is no data there).

According to the author, S( 1 , 0 ) = delta( x_1 , GAP) so P(1,1) = delta( GAP , y_1 ) + delta( x_1 , GAP)
history.subject: 6.26 base cases
